claims.claim: Incarcerated individuals can gain valuable legal and technical skills through prison programs.
claims.quote: While I'm incarcerated, I end up signing up for what's called the Legal Writer Program. So I'm really, I'm like pretty good at the law because, I was trying to appeal my own case. And so just, by circumstance I became educated [...] I then had access to a laptop. I had to go through a training. I had to, 'cause I had to prepare folks legal brief.

claims.claim: Engaging in productive activities while incarcerated, like the Legal Writer Program, can pay better than other prison jobs.
claims.quote: ironically enough, they were gonna pay me, which is the highest rate anyone in the MDOC can get, Like it was, it was, it was the baller status of $3 34 cents a day.

claims.claim: Prison jobs that involve legal work and technology training are highly valued and better compensated.
claims.quote: they were gonna pay me, which is the highest rate anyone in the MDOC can get, Like it was, it was, it was the baller status of $3 34 cents a day.

claims.claim: Access to technology like laptops in prison significantly helps with reintegration and adapting to modern tools post-release.
claims.quote: So that meant that every day. I was at a laptop, at a desktop, and at one point even I had a little notebook. They had something happened wrong with the desktop and they gave us these little notebooks, So I was having this daily connection and understanding with how to navigate windows and sub folders, Graphic user interfaces, all of that.

claims.claim: Formerly incarcerated individuals may experience anxiety over losing or damaging personal technology devices post-release.
claims.quote: When I first got my, when I got my first phone, maybe the first couple weeks I was home, I used to have nightmares about breaking it. I would have literal nightmares where I would wake up thinking I had broken my phone or dropped it.
